metadata.title: A Simple Scoring Method for Predicting the Low Risk of Persistent Acute Kidney Injury in Critically Ill Adult Patients

BIBREF0.title: Identifying critically ill patients at high risk for developing acute renal failure: a pilot study

TABREF0.text: The risk factors for AKI (adapted and modified from reference (1)) SupplementalTable 2. The unadjusted odds ratios of ∆Cr between ICU admission and the following daySupplemental Table 3. The adjusted odds ratio of each factor for outcome in the discovery cohort. The ventilator and/or vasoactive factor was shown to be the highest risk factor. The hyperbilirubinemia and sepsis factors represent moderate risk of persistent AKI.

TABREF1.text: The predictive performance of each PARI cut-off in the discovery cohort.SupplementalTable 5. The predictive performance of each PARI cut-off in the validation cohort.

TABREF2.text: Table 1: The risk factors for AKI (adapted and modified from reference (1) )
TABREF2.html:
Older age ≥70 yrs  
Diabetes mellitus History of diabetes mellitus vascular disease
Cardiovascular disease History of angina pectoris, coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, heart failure, or peripheral
Chronic kidney disease Baseline eGFR <60mL/min/1.73m2
Hypertension History of hypertension or patients chronic antihypertensive medication receiving
Morbid obesity BMI >30.0 kg/m2  
Hyperbilirubinemia Serum total bilirubin >2.0 mg/dL
Cerebrovascular accident History of any type of cerebrovascular accident
Cancer surgical care) Active cancer (patients not in remission and without
High‐risk surgery (excluding cholecystectomy) and non ‐ steroidal anti ‐ admission. Cardiac surgery (valvular or coronary artery bypass grafting), aortic surgery, hepatobiliary surgery
Nephrotoxin exposure Amphotericin B, aminoglycosides, vancomycin, inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) excluding aspirin given prior to or at ICU
Sepsis acute change in total SOFA score ≥2. Existence of infection treated with antibiotics and life-threatening organ dysfunction identified as an
Ventilator and/or vasopressor The use of ventilator and/or vasoactive drugs such as norepinephrine, epinephrine, dobutamine and
 dopamine.

TABREF4.text: Table 3. The adjusted odds ratio of each factor for outcome in the discovery cohort. The ventilator and/or vasoactive factor was shown to be the highest risk factor. The hyperbilirubinemia and sepsis factors represent moderate risk of persistent AKI.
TABREF4.html:
Condition Odds ratio
Age ≥70 1.16 (0.94-1.42)
Diabetes mellitus 1.07 (0.86-1.32)
Cardiovascular disease 0.84 (0.67-1.05)
CKD 1.20 (0.97-1.49)
Hypertension 0.80 (0.66-0.98)
Morbid obesity 0.94 (0.56-1.50)
Hyperbilirubinemia (≥2.0 mg/dL) 1.45 (1.03-2.03)
Cerebrovascular accident 0.70 (0.53-0.91)
Cancer 0.85 (0.61-1.17)
High-risk surgery 1.20 (0.96-1.49)
Nephrotoxic drugs 0.81 (0.60-1.09)
Sepsis 1.53 (1.25-1.89)
Ventilator or vasoactive 3.51 (2.85-4.35)
